challenge.description: Conventional solid-state reaction methods for synthesizing o-LiMnO2 require high temperatures (700–1050 °C) and involve complicated powder preparation routes, including multiple calcination and physical grinding steps.
challenge.impact: The complexity and high-temperature requirements make the synthesis process inefficient and less practical for large-scale production.

solution.description: A low-temperature hydrothermal approach using fine Mn3O4 and aqueous LiOH solution was developed to synthesize o-LiMnO2 at 170 °C.
solution.methodology: Hydrothermal treatment with controlled LiOH concentration and temperature conditions.
solution.effectiveness: The hydrothermal method successfully produced high-quality o-LiMnO2 with well-ordered orthorhombic crystallinity, demonstrating its effectiveness as a simpler and more efficient synthesis route.

evidence.data: XRD patterns confirmed the formation of o-LiMnO2 as the major phase at 3.5 M LiOH concentration, and Rietveld refinement showed well-ordered orthorhombic crystallinity.

context.material_properties: Orthorhombic structure with zigzag layer arrangement, high theoretical capacity.
context.experimental_conditions: Hydrothermal treatment at 170 °C with varying LiOH concentrations.
context.application_relevance: Simplified synthesis of o-LiMnO2 as a promising cathode material for Li-ion batteries.

challenge.description: High capacity loss (~95 mAh/g) was observed during the first cycling of o-LiMnO2 electrodes.
challenge.impact: The significant capacity loss reduces the initial performance and long-term reliability of the material as a cathode in Li-ion batteries.

solution.description: Cycle-induced spinel phase formation was observed to stabilize the material and improve capacity retention over subsequent cycles.
solution.methodology: Electrochemical cycling to induce structural reordering toward spinel-like phases.
solution.effectiveness: The spinel-like phase demonstrated tolerance to cycling and contributed to increased capacity in the 4-V region, stabilizing after 40 cycles with a discharge capacity of ~140 mAh/g.

evidence.data: Charge-discharge profiles showed progressive stabilization of capacity after 40 cycles, with improved performance compared to conventional spinel LiMn2O4.

context.material_properties: Cycle-induced spinel phase formation improves cycling stability and capacity retention.
context.experimental_conditions: Electrochemical testing at 0.1 mA/cm² current density and 25 °C.
context.application_relevance: Enhanced cycling stability and capacity retention make o-LiMnO2 suitable for long-term use in Li-ion batteries.
